{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Independent Theatre Pakistan | logo = itc-logo.png | caption = The logo of Independent Theatre Pakistan | trading_name = | native_name = | foundation = {{Start date and age|2012|03|23|df=y}} | founder = Azeem Hamid | type = Performing arts organization | industry = Entertainment | genre = Urdu and English plays, storytelling, musicals, theatre education, promotion of literature and theatre both professionally and in the community | location_city = [[Lahore]], [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]] | location_country = [[Pakistan]] | locations = | area_served = Pakistan | key_people = Azeem Hamid and Omer T. Jilani | homepage = {{URL|independenttheatrepk.com/}} | intl = }}
'''Independent Theatre Pakistan''' (often abbreviated to '''ITP''') is a [[Pakistan]]i [[theater company|theatre company]] and [[performing arts]] organization based in [[Lahore]], [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]], established in March 2012.<ref name="interview-founderitc">{{cite web | url=http://ideasevolved.com/tete-a-tete-with-azeem-hamid/ | title=Tete-a-Tete with Azeem Hamid | publisher=IdeasEvolved.com | access-date=8 January 2015 }}</ref> The group is directed by founder, writer and director Azeem Hamid, who was soon joined with designer Danyaal Syed.<ref name="interview-founderitc"/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.youlinmagazine.com/article/azeem-hamid-and-the-independent-theatre-company/MzAw | title=Azeem Hamid and the Independent Theatre Company | publisher=YoulinMagazine.com | access-date=8 January 2015 }}</ref> It is the youngest theatre company in continuous production to have performed both internationally and domestically from Pakistan. Since their inception, the group has performed over twenty theatrical productions.
The group primarily performs in [[Urdu language]] but has also done theatrical productions in [[English language|English]] and [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] languages.<ref name=interview-founderitc/> They have extensively focused on the revival of [[Urdu literature]] in Pakistan.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tweetistan.com/theatre-production-houses-in-pakistan-are-giving-wings-to-talent/ | title=Theatre Production Houses in Pakistan are Giving Wings to Talent!!! | publisher=Tweetistan.com | access-date=16 July 2016 }}</ref>
Independent Theatre Pakistan have produced original theatrical productions such as ''Awaaz'' (literal translation: ''Voice''), a [[psychological thriller]] play and the [[satirical]] short-play ''Kuttay'' (literal translation: ''Dogs''). Also, they have adapted the works of progressive [[South Asian]] writers like [[Saadat Hassan Manto]], [[Rajinder Singh Bedi]], [[Krishan Chander]], [[Imtiaz Ali Taj]], [[Ashfaq Ahmed]] and [[Meerza Adeeb]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S9pr6nhXZd4| title=Independent Theatre Pakistan Top #7 Facts| publisher=YouTube.com| accessdate=2016-04-04 }}</ref>
==History==
===Formation (2012)=== [[File:zarapeerzada-itp.jpg|thumb|right|250px| [[Zara Peerzada]] as "Saugandi" in [[Saadat Hasan Manto|Manto]]'s ''Hatak (Insult)'' directed by Azeem Hamid at Alhamra Arts Council, [[Lahore]], in 2012]] The company was founded in 2012 by [[Azeem Hamid]] and Danyaal Syed and now operates all across theatres in [[Lahore]]: [[Alhamra Arts Council]] and [[Ali Institute of Education|Ali Auditorium]] (for classical [[Urdu language|Urdu]] & [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] plays and musicals) and different educational institutes (for theatre workshops & short plays).
Their first theatrical production ''Hatak'' (literal meaning: ''Insult''),<ref>{{cite web | url=http://jang.com.pk/thenews/Nov2012-weekly/nos-04-11-2012/she.htm#4 | title=Shehr, NOS, Town Talk | publisher=Jang.com | access-date=2015-01-08 }}</ref> featured fashion model and actress [[Zara Peerzada]] in the lead role,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.newslinemagazine.com/2014/07/interview-zara-peerzada/ | title=Interview: Zara Peerzada | publisher=newslinemagazine.com | accessdate=2015-01-08 }}</ref> was based on the short-story of famous Urdu writer [[Saadat Hassan Manto]], staged in November 2012 at Alhamra Arts Council and received positive reviews from critics.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2CkBwLYzCDs | title=Drama 'Hatak' presented in Alhamra report by Raza Zaidi| publisher=City42 | accessdate=2015-01-08 }}</ref> This was followed by the group collaborating with [[Beaconhouse School System|Beaconhouse School Liberty]] for a theatrical performance ''Dareecha'', based loosely on the writings of the play ''Qurtaba Ka Qazi'' written by [[Imtiaz Ali Taj]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://jang.com.pk/thenews/Nov2012-weekly/nos-11-11-2012/she.htm#3 | title=Shehr, NOS, Town Talk Nov 11-2012 | publisher=Jang.com | accessdate=2015-01-08 }}</ref>
===Early years (2013)=== In 2013, the group initiated their year with two short-length plays; ''Dastak (The Knock)'', a play written by [[Meerza Adeeb]] and an original, ''Awaaz (Voice)'', in collaboration with [[Lahore Grammar School]], the latter winning two-awards at Colors & Humour 2013 for the best actress & supporting actor roles. This success was later followed by a sold-out performance of [[Ashfaq Ahmed]]'s tele-play stage adaptation ''Fehmida Ki Kahani, Ustaani Rahat Ki Zubani'' in March, the performance was praised by many literature writers including [[Ayub Khawar]]. The group went on to perform [[Rajinder Singh Bedi]]'s classical satire ''Naql-e-Makani (Moving to a New House)'' from 4th till 6 October,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AxP_cLCyMZ4 | title=Famous Novel 'Naql-e-Makani' by Rajinder Singh Bedi to be performed in Lahore report by Mukarram Kaleem| publisher=City42 | accessdate=2015-01-08 }}</ref> which was well received by critics and the audiences.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/national/05-Oct-2013/bedi-s-naql-e-makani-being-staged-at-ali-auditorium | title=Bedi's 'Naql-e-Makani' being staged at Ali Auditorium | publisher=Daily Times | accessdate=2015-01-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7PAR2ZuFX8A | title='Naql-e-Makani' report by Mukarram Kaleem| publisher=City42 | accessdate=2015-01-08 }}</ref> In the same month, Azeem Hamid directed ''Kuttay'', a satirical performance based on the writings of [[Nadeem F. Paracha]]'s article ''Dog Gone''<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1046970 | title=Dog Gone by Nadeem F. Paracha | publisher=Dawn News | accessdate=2016-04-04}}</ref> as a mock to society. The performance won the [[Imtiaz Ali Taj]] award at a festival held in Lahore, [[Pakistan]].
===International success (2014–2015)=== The following year, it produced several performances, which included ''Jhelum Mein Naupar'' ''(The Sailing Boat in Jhelum)'' featuring stage actress [[Amtul Baweja]] and an adaptation of [[Reginald Rose]]'s famous film ''[[Twelve Angry Men]]'' as ''[[Twelve Angry Men (play)|Twelve Angry Jurors]]''<ref>{{cite web | url=http://issuu.com/pakistantoday-paperazzi/docs/pakistan_today_paperazzi_issue_25_f | title=Paperazzi Magazine Issue #25 | publisher=Paperazzi Magazine | accessdate=2016-04-04}}</ref> at different venues in Lahore. In summers, the group went on their first international tour at the [[SPIC MACAY|2nd International SPIC MACAY Convention]] held in [[Chennai]], [[Madras]], [[India]] where they collaborated with [[Koodiyattam]] master Margi Madhu from the [[Chakyar]] clan for the classical [[Sanskrit theatre]] performance of ''Anguliyankam (The Golden Ring)'' in June 2014.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-fridayreview/beyond-boundaries/article6152740.ece | title=Beyond Borders | publisher=The Hindu| accessdate=2016-04-04 }}</ref> [[File:faizan-itp.jpg|thumb|left|250px| [[Saadat Hasan Manto|Manto]]'s ''Kamra #9 (Room No. 9)'' directed by Azeem Hamid at [[Alhamra Arts Council]], [[Lahore]], in 2014. Visible from left to right: Faizan Naveed as "Nasir", Namwar Ayaz as "Zamaan" and Zoya Uzair as "Shireen".]]
In December, the company went on to produce their best known theatrical performance ''[[Kamra No. 9]] (Room No. 9)'' a [[radio play]] written by [[Saadat Hasan Manto]] and directed by Azeem Hamid. The performance was well received by critics and audiences, the ''[[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]]'' wrote "''Kamra #9'' ... mystery musical is an example of [[Urdu Theater|Urdu theatre]] at its finest."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/entertainment/12-Dec-2014/kamra-9-opens-in-lahore | title=Kamra #9 opens in Lahore.| publisher=Daily Times| accessdate=2016-04-04 }}</ref> [[Shoaib Ahmed (journalist)|Shoaib Ahmed]] of ''[[Dawn Newspaper]]'' wrote "The 60-minute three-act play had such a strong production value that it kept glued the audience to their seats till the end. The literary piece was deeply and meaningfully tailored for the play.",<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1150088/mantos-kamra-number-9-at-alhamra | title=Manto’s Kamra Number 9 at Alhamra | publisher=Dawn News | accessdate=2015-01-08}}</ref> while during an interview to ''[[The Express Tribune]]'', director Azeem Hamid said, "Visualising and creating a 1930s [[Delhi]] feel for a radio play was an immense challenge; we walked around Jalander, India to get inspiration for ''Kamra #9’s'' set design."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/805298/a-room-full-of-mantos-imagination/ | title=A room full of Manto’s imagination | publisher=The Express Tribune | accessdate=2015-01-08 }}</ref> The ''[[Mani-Nama]]'' blog reviewed the performance saying, "The set was quite modest- a realistic one with an old radio, telephone and chairs. After sometime I witnessed some quality lighting which was done by Shakeel Siddique, who literally set the pace of play with classic lights."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://the-mani-nama.blogspot.com/2014/12/by-hammad-anwar-follow-manihammad-about.html | title=Meeting Manto`s mysterious occupant of Kamra#9| publisher=The Mani-Nama Blog| accessdate=2016-04-04 }}</ref> and ''[[The News International|The News on Sunday]]'' wrote, "''Kamra #9'' provided insight into human complexities."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tns.thenews.com.pk/manto-play-kamra-number-9-on-stage/#.VwQ54uaxkXh | title=Kamra with a view| publisher=The News on Sunday| accessdate=2016-04-04 }}</ref> [[Aleeza Rasool]], writer and critic, of ''[[Youlin Magazine]]'' reported praising the performance as she wrote, "Firstly, a radio play by Manto was a refreshing choice, for it is one of the lesser-known genres that Manto composed during his brief lifetime. Secondly, the play was very well-acted, and most importantly, the direction was even-tempered, making the play engaging., adding that, "It is unusual to come across the genus of anticipation and suspense in [[Theatre in Pakistan|Pakistani stage plays]], which is why Azeem Hamid, actor and director of the play, deserves a pat on the back for putting up a wonderful performance on Manto’s radio play."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.youlinmagazine.com/blog/stage-play-kamra-no-9/MTA3 | title=The Mysterious Resident of Kamra No. 9| publisher=Youlin Magazine| accessdate=2016-04-04}}</ref>
After the success in Pakistan, the company went on to perform ''Kamra No. 9'' in [[West Bengal]], India to promote peace between the two bordering nations.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1141225/jsp/siliguri/story_5164.jsp | title=Santipur stage for theatre festival| publisher=The Telegraph India | accessdate=2015-01-08}}</ref> During an interview with ''[[The Telegraph (Calcutta)|The Telegraph]]'', "For the past few years, the theatre and cultural activists have been protesting in various ways against fanaticism, trying their best to educate people in rural areas, organising workshops in schools and colleges and staging street theatres. We were hopeful that a peaceful atmosphere would gradually emerge. The [[2014 Peshawar school massacre|Peshawar killings]] have come as an eye-opener," [[Zoya Uzair]], who played the lead role of 'Shireen', said.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1141228/jsp/bengal/story_19267064.jsp | title=Pak Theatre's message of Peace| publisher=The Telegraph India| accessdate=2016-04-04 }}</ref> The company's director Azeem Hamid received an 'Address of Honour' from [[Member of the Legislative Assembly|MLA]] [[Ajoy Dey]] of the [[Santipur (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Santipur Municipality]] for staging and directing ''Kamra No. 9'' in West Bengal. [[File:rashidmehmood-itp.jpg|thumb|right|250px| [[Rashid Mehmood (actor)|Rashid Mehmood]] starred as "Fakir" alongside Shafaq Yousuf as "Munni" in ''Sammi Di Vaar'' staged in [[Lahore]], 2015.]]
In 2015, director Azeem Hamid said in an interview to ''[[My Awesome Journey]]'' that "I decided to revamp ITP. I had been scouting a team of professionals that would be useful in creating intelligent theatre."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.myawesomejourney.com/?p=645 | title=Meet: The Very Talented – Azeem Hamid, Founder and CEO at Independent Theatre Pakistan| publisher=My Awesome Journey| accessdate=2016-04-04 }}</ref> The company supported 'The End Polio Now' campaign organized by [[Rotary International]] at [[Alhamra Arts Council]], [[Lahore]] and performed an original monologue ''Scream'' at the event. In December, the group produced a set of three theatrical performances, ''3 Kahaniyan (Three Stories)'' which featured ''Bu (Odour)'' an original play written by [[University of Regina]] graduate Ayesha Mohsin having previously worked with [[CJTR-FM]], a [[Punjabi language]] play ''Sammi Di Vaar (Sammi's Life)'' written by [[Najm Hosain Syed]] and directed by Mehreen Mir from [[Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts]], [[London]] which featured famous Pakistani film actor [[Rashid Mehmood (actor)|Rashid Mehmood]], and a stage adaptation of [[Saadat Hasan Manto]]'s short-story ''Badshahat Ka Khatma (Kingdom's End)'' by Azeem Hamid.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1218888 | title=Theatre group unfolds ‘3 Kahaniyan’ from 30th| publisher=Dawn News| accessdate=2016-04-04 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theworldofhsy.com/independent-theater-pakistan/ | title=3 Kahaniyan: Independent Theatre Pakistan| publisher=The World of HSY| access-date=4 April 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2015/11/28/entertainment/teen-kahaniyan-is-ready-to-buzkasha/ | title=Teen Kahaniyan is ready to BUZKASHA!| publisher=Pakistan Today| access-date=4 April 2016 }}</ref> ''[[The Pakistan Today]]'' reported that ''3 Kahaniyan'' received a mixed reception from critics,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2015/12/01/entertainment/3-kahaniyan-finally-told/| title=Teen Kahaniyan finally told| publisher=Pakistan Today| access-date=4 April 2016 }}</ref> while Faizan Javed of ''[[The Nation (Pakistan)|The Nation]]'' praised the performance writing "The immediate response of the audience determines the quality of play being stage. And when it comes to social message for the audience the impact is everlasting. The play ''3 Kahaniyan'' being staged at [[Alhamra Arts Council|Alhamra Hall]] on [[Mall Road, Lahore|Mall Road]] is an example."<ref>{{cite web | date=3 December 2015 | url=http://nation.com.pk/entertainment/03-Dec-2015/absurdity-in-all-its-right| title=Absurdity in all its right| publisher=The Nation| access-date=4 April 2016 }}</ref>
===Rise to fame (2016)=== In March, the company produced the theatrical adaptation of [[Neil Simon]]'s [[Farce|farcical]] play ''[[Rumors (play)|Rumors]]'', which was praised and supported by well known celebrities and film stars like [[Agha Ali]], [[Cybil J. Chowdhry]], [[Poonam Anwar]], [[Rachel Gill]] and comedian [[Ali Sufian Wasif]]. The performance was a sold-out show. Soon after, team members from the company participated and lead a delegation to [[SPIC MACAY|4th International Convention of SPIC MACAY]] held in [[IIT Guwahati]], [[Assam]], [[India]]. In September, [[University of Veterinary and Animal Sciences]] hosted a three-days theatrical workshops program called 'Dramaship', which featured lectures from the group team members including Azeem Hamid and Faiz Rasool.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://pakistannewsreleases.com/3-days-theatre-workshop-title-dramaship-concludes-at-university-of-veterinary-and-animal-sciences/| title=3-days Theatre workshop title Dramaship concludes at University of Veterinary and Animal Sciences | publisher=www.pakistannewsreleases.com | access-date=8 September 2016}}</ref> The objective of the workshop focused to gather talented students at a single platform and develop their theatrical skills so that they can explore and learn basic concepts of theatre in a new medium to translate their expression.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.pakistanpoint.com/en/pakistan/news/3-day-theatre-workshop-concludes-at-uvas-26500.html | title=3-day Theatre Workshop Concludes At UVAS | publisher=Pakistan Point |accessdate=2016-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.uvas.edu.pk/Press_Release/2016/Sep/08/press2.htm | title=3-days Theatre workshop title "Dramaship" concludes at UVAS | publisher=www.uvas.edu.pk | access-date=8 September 2016}}</ref>
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:arsenic-itp.jpg|thumb|left|250px| [[Joseph Kesselring]]'s ''[[Arsenic and Old Lace (play)|Arsenic & Old Lace]]'' directed by Azeem Hamid and Shabee-ul-Hassan staged in [[Ali Institute of Education|Ali Auditorium]], [[Lahore]], 2016]] --> On 20 October, Hamid announced that the company will be directing and producing three full-length comedy theatrical performances which includes ''[[Arsenic and Old Lace (play)|Arsenic and Old Lace]]'', ''[[Run for Your Wife (play)|Run for Your Wife]]'' and ''[[Around the World (musical)|Around the World in 80 Days]]''. In an interview with ''[[Daily Pakistan]]'', "I’m excited and looking forward to November. Rehearsals are in full swing at the [[Lahore Grammar School]] Gulberg these days, and after that we will be moving on to [[The City School (Pakistan)|The City School]]. It is going to be a dream come true for theatre lovers, as we keep on working towards the revival of theatre culture in Pakistan", said Azeem Hamid, creative director of the company.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://en.dailypakistan.com.pk/lifestyle/daily-pakistan-global-collaborates-with-independent-theatre-pakistan-to-bring-you-jam-packed-theatres-this-november/ | title=Daily Pakistan Global collaborates with Independent Theatre Pakistan to bring you jam-packed halls this November! | publisher=Daily Pakistan | accessdate=2016-10-20}}</ref> ''[[The Nation (Pakistan)|The Nation]]'' reported that the company will be presenting [[Joseph Kesselring]]'s famous black comedy ''Arsenic and Old Lace'' on 19 November in [[Lahore]], [[Pakistan]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.anotao.com/link/pk/2016110194117/nation.com.pk/lahore/17-Nov-2016/what-s-on | title=What's on | publisher=The Nation Pakistan | accessdate=2016-11-17}}</ref>
On 25 November, [[Sana Gilani]] from the ''Daily Pakistan'' published, a review of the performance ''Arsenic and Old Lace'' staged on 19 November, saying "Independent Theatre put forth an amazingly hilarious play" while adding that "Azeem Hamid of Independent Theatre Pakistan put his best foot forward and directed the play’s adaptation."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://en.dailypakistan.com.pk/campus-news/arsenic-old-lace-play-highlights-lgs-15-c-itp-collaboration/ | title=Arsenic & Old Lace: Play Highlights [LGS 15-C & ITP Collaboration] | publisher=Daily Pakistan | accessdate=2016-11-25}}</ref> A week later, [[Faiz Rasool]] directed a re-enactment of a comedy by [[Ray Cooney]], which received applause and appreciation from the audiences and critics, ''Daily Pakistan'' reported calling the play a remarkable success and saying, "''Run For Your Wife'' on the 26th and 27th of November, 2016; with a full-house for both days... Jam-packed audiences were delving deeply into the story, and the suspense & humour was one to not have missed."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://en.dailypakistan.com.pk/campus-news/arsenic-old-lace-play-highlights-lgs-15-c-itp-collaboration/ | title=Independent Theatre Pakistan’s second play ‘Run For Your WIFE’: Remarkably successful! | publisher=Daily Pakistan | accessdate=2016-11-29}}</ref>
In December, the group founded the ''[[ASSITEJ|ASSITEJ Pakistan National Center]]'' in alliance with professionals involved in [[Theatre for Early Years|theatre for children]] and young people in Pakistan, with the aim of hosting a [[performing arts]] festival the following year in [[Lahore]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.assitej-international.org/?wysija-page=1&controller=email&action=view&email_id=45&wysijap=subscriptions | title=ASSITEJ Newsletter 83 | publisher=ASSITEJ International | accessdate=2017-02-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.assitej-international.org/en/2017/02/assitej-pakistan-is-here/ | title=ASSITEJ Pakistan is here! | publisher=ASSITEJ International | accessdate=2017-02-01}}</ref>
===Continued success (2017–present)=== Independent Theatre Pakistan team announced that they will be hosting and organizing the biggest children's performing arts festival, ''Tamasha Festival'', to be held on the 7th, 8th and 9th of April at [[Alhamra Arts Council]], in [[Lahore]], [[Pakistan]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://en.dailypakistan.com.pk/lifestyle/lahores-most-anticipated-tamasha-festival-2017-is-just-around-the-corner/ | title=Lahore’s most anticipated “Tamasha Festival 2017” is just around the corner | publisher=Daily Pakistan | accessdate=2017-03-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://en.dailypakistan.com.pk/lifestyle/announcing-the-7th-assitej-asia-meet-and-first-ever-performing-arts-festival-tamasha-for-young-audiences-from-7th-to-9th-april-2017-alhamra-arts-council-lahore/ | title=Announcing the 7th ASSITEJ Asia Meet and first ever performing arts festival “TAMASHA” for young audiences from 7th to 9th April, 2017 – Alhamra Arts Council, Lahore | publisher=Daily Pakistan | accessdate=2017-04-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.brecorder.com/2017/04/06/342128/tamasha-festival-2017-to-begin-in-lahore-this-week/ | title=Tamasha Festival 2017 to begin in Lahore this week | publisher=Business Recorder | accessdate=2017-04-06}}</ref> On April 7th, ''[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]'' reported during the opening of the festivity that "The festival presents theatre performances for young, training workshops from upcoming directors, master workshops from international trainers for local artists and discussion sessions for general public."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1325610 | title=Tamasha Festival opens at Alhamra| publisher=Dawn News | accessdate=2017-04-08}}</ref> While Faizan Javed from ''[[The Nation (Pakistan)|The Nation]]'' reportedly said "The opening ceremony was attended by special guests and people from the theatre and performing arts such as [[Salima Hashmi]], Bina Jawaad and Information, Culture and Youth Affairs Minister Mujtaba Shujaur Rehman as honorable chief guest."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nation.com.pk/newspaper-picks/08-Apr-2017/tamasha-underway | title=Tamasha underway| publisher=The Nation | accessdate=2017-04-08}}</ref> Salima Hashmi in an interview with ''The Nation'' in regards to the festivity said, “When I first performed in Alhamra there was no fancy set, props and sound system. There was nothing but a garden with a hut. But then it was a significant experience in my life and I learnt a great deal from it. We should appreciate the young talent because these young people are our future”.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nation.com.pk/entertainment/07-Apr-2017/tamasha-festival-begins-in-lahore | title=Tamasha begins in Lahore| publisher=The Nation | accessdate=2017-04-07}}</ref>
''The Nation'' newspaper reported on the second day of ''[[Tamasha Festival]]'', saying "thought provoking panel discussions explored the creativity to entertain and educate children...What’s theatre for children? One of the most interesting sessions was with [[Asaya Fujita]] and [[Sue Giles]]. Moderated by Sarah Zahid the discussion among panelists was remarkable. The session held at [[Alhamra Arts Council]] - Hall 1, highlighted the importance of theatre and arts for children. Director of [[Polyglot Theatre]], Sue Giles said that through theatre, we achieve an opportunity to present space and time to subjective experience and nourish the child’s brain power. “The idea of ‘value for money’ is another issue how people perceive the place and power of children in our midst. We neglect our children’s physical freedoms we once had,” Sue added. While the session ‘Society and Drama’ highlighted the issues of theatre industry in both countries Pakistan and Korea. The session was moderated by [[Azeem Hamid]] and the panelists were renowned writer [[Asghar Nadeem Syed]] and [[Seok Hong-Kim]]."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nation.com.pk/lahore/09-Apr-2017/tamasha-day-2 | title=Tamasha Day 2| publisher=The Nation | accessdate=2017-04-09}}</ref>
On 19 May, the company produced the theatrical adaptations of [[Jules Verne]]'s ''[[Around the World (musical)|Around the World in 80 Days]]'' and [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Julius Caesar (play)|Julius Caesar]]'', directed by Syed Shabee-ul-Hassan.
==Educational programming== Independent Theatre Pakistan theatrical workshops use the art of acting and [[storytelling]] as a model for creative thinking in general. The company's director, Azeem Hamid in a radio interview to [[Fifi Haroon]] from ''[[BBC Urdu]]'' said, "Teaching creative expressions like theatre play an important role in building confidence skills, enhancing leadership qualities and empowering empathy to children. Storytelling methods and techniques are very vital to teach a subject much more creatively to a student."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.com/urdu/multimedia/2015/09/150920_rabt_interview_fifi_sq| title=’بچوں کو سوال کرنے دیں‘| publisher=BBC Urdu| accessdate=2016-04-04 }}</ref> The group have collaborated extensively with leading [[Private school|private]] as well as public educational institutions such as [[Lahore Grammar School]], [[The City School (Pakistan)|The City School]], [[Beaconhouse School System]], [[Beaconhouse National University]], [[Institute of Business Administration, Karachi]] and non-for-profit organizations like [[Rabtt]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://rabtt.org/rabtt-blue-book/ | title=Rabtt - Blue Book| publisher=Rabtt.org | accessdate=2017-05-20}}</ref> to promote [[theatre]] and [[literature]] in [[Pakistan]].
The group have also worked with [[Justice Project Pakistan]], a non-for-profit organization, campaigning to raise awareness on the fundamental rights of ordinary citizens living in Pakistan with a series of flash performances across the streets of Lahore.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/1152116/ignorance-law-not-know-kill/| title=‘What you do not know could kill you’| publisher=Urooj Sultan, [[The Express Tribune]]| accessdate=2016-07-29 }}</ref>
The company members were featured in a documentary aired on the television show ''[[Kahani Pakistani]]'' of ''[[Voice of America| Voice of America Urdu]]'', hosted by [[Ayesha Gilani]], where they talked about "The importance of theatre and how the art of performing arts is a reflection of our lives in Pakistan." in January 2016.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.urduvoa.com/media/video/kahani-pakistani-art-reflection-lives/3156322.html| title=کہانی پاکستانی:Art- Reflection of Our Lives| publisher=Voice of America Urdu| accessdate=2016-04-04 }}</ref> The company continues to offer several week-long workshops and classes to individuals who wish to excel in theatre production, performance and education; providing a platform for young aspiring Pakistani artists to excel in their creative pursuits.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://changemakerxchange.com/azeem-hamid/ | title=Azeem Hamid - ChangemakersXchange | publisher=ChangemakersXchange.com | accessdate=2017-05-20}}</ref> Azeem Hamid in an interview with ''[[My Voice Unheard]]'' said, "Currently, we are doing extensive research on the performing arts culture in Pakistan. We are carrying out an innovative, youth centered theatrical program and ingenious curriculum across the nation.", adding, "Our productions focus on Pakistani values with a spotlight on creating cross cultural dialogue through means of creative expression."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://myvoiceunheard.com/azeem-hamid-itp/ | title=Azeem Hamid - Redefining Theatrical Arts | publisher=My Voice Unheard | accessdate=2016-11-24}}</ref>
As part of ''[[ASSITEJ|ASSITEJ Pakistan National Centre]]'', the company hosted and organized the 7th edition of the annual ''ASSITEJ Asia Meeting'' which was held at Lahore from April 6–7, 2017. This was followed by organizing the ''Tamasha Festival'' which showcased 8 theatre, dance and music performances by professional groups, 21 theatre performances by schools and 10 performing arts workshops for children and young audience with 8 discussion sessions about performing arts and theatre for children and young audience with well-known performing arts personalities.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.assitej-international.org/en/2017/05/7th-assitej-asia-meeting-was-held-at-lahore-pakistan-from-april-6-7-2017/ | title=7th ASSITEJ Asia Meeting was held at Lahore, Pakistan from April 6 – 7, 2017. | publisher=ASSITEJ International | accessdate=2017-05-01}}</ref>
==Productions==
Independent Theatre Pakistan has staged several full length and short length plays in Urdu, English, Hindi and Punjabi languages.
{{colbegin|colwidth=33em}} * 2012: ''[[Heer Ranjha]]'', by [[Waris Shah]] * 2012: ''[[Saadat Hassan Manto|Hatak]]'', by [[Saadat Hassan Manto]] * 2012: ''[[Imtiaz Ali Taj|Dareecha]]'', by [[Imtiaz Ali Taj]] * 2013: ''Awaaz'', by Azeem Hamid * 2013: ''Dastak'', by [[Meerza Adeeb]] * 2013: ''[[Ashfaq Ahmed|Fehmida Ki Kahani, Ustaani Rahat Ki Zubani]]'', by [[Ashfaq Ahmed]] * 2013: ''Kuttay'', by Azeem Hamid * 2013: ''Naql-e-Makani'', by [[Rajinder Singh Bedi]] * 2014: ''[[Krishan Chander|Jhelum Mein Naupar]]'', by [[Krishan Chander]] * 2014: ''[[Twelve Angry Men (play)|Twelve Angry Jurors]]'', by [[Reginald Rose]] * 2014: ''Anguliyankam'' ''(Single Act from Ascharya Choodamani)'', by Sakthibhadra * 2014: ''[[Kamra No. 9]]'', by Saadat Hassan Manto * 2015: ''Scream'', by Mehreen Abid Mir * 2015: ''Aao Baat Tu Suno'', by Saadat Hassan Manto * 2015: ''3 Kahaniyan'' ''(Bu, Sammi Di Vaar, Badshahat Ka Khatma)'', by Ayesha Mohsin, [[Najm Hosain Syed]] and Azeem Hamid * 2016: ''[[Rumors (play)|Rumors]]'', by [[Neil Simon]] * 2016: ''Koi Bhi, Kahin Bhi, Kisi Bhi Waqt'', by Mehreen Abid Mir * 2016: ''[[Arsenic and Old Lace (play)|Arsenic and Old Lace]]'', by [[Joseph Kesselring]] * 2016: ''[[Run for Your Wife (play)|Run for Your Wife]]'', by [[Ray Cooney]] * 2017: ''[[Julius Caesar (play)|Julius Caesar]]'', by [[William Shakespeare]] * 2017: ''[[Around the World (musical)|Around the World in 80 Days]]'', by [[Jules Verne]] * 2017: ''[[The Odd Couple (play)|The Odd Couple]]'', by Neil Simon * 2017: ''[[Lend Me a Tenor]]'', by [[Ken Ludwig]] * 2018: ''[[Macbeth]]'', by William Shakespeare * 2018: ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1902 musical)|The Wizard of Oz]]'', by [[L. Frank Baum]] * 2018: ''Pirates of the Currybean'', by Craig Hawes {{colend}}
==Awards and Accolades== Independent Theatre Pakistan won the "Best Supporting Role" and "Best Actor" awards at the [[Lahore Grammar School]]'s Colors & Humor festival in Lahore in 2013. The company won the "[[Imtiaz Ali Taj]]" award for their performance ''Kuttay'' in Lahore followed by winning "Best Play" and "Best Actor" awards at the [[Beaconhouse National University|BNU Bestival]] 2014. The company's first international award came with the performance of ''Kamra #9 (Room No. 9)'' at Rangapeeth Natyamela held in December 2014, in [[West Bengal]], [[India]]. They have also been awarded for their contribution towards peace by MLA Ajoy Dey of the [[Santipur (Vidhan Sabha constituency)|Santipur Municipality]].
==See also== * [[Theatre of Pakistan]]
